content: This contribution hasnâ€™t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

I am so lost.. xD 

is there a link to a video or blog to this problem so I can visually see what's happening. I am curious.
Well it took *me* more than a minute anyway.

am i wrong or is it just a trivial problem of ceiled minimum and maximum distances in a group of points ?

so first time players have to translate boring text to know what to do while others solve it in less than 1 minute ... not fair

Nice Task! It took me a bit longer than I expected :)
However, I dearly missed the print to stderr stub.
Please add it to the code, as it can make life so much easier.
min_diff + max_diff ??? No
Does question 2 mean that each circle intersects each other circle, or just that the circles form a connected network?

I have several considaritions with this problem.
First of all a circle has radius greater than 0 by definition.
When you say a circle is given by its coordinate I suppose you mean its centre is given.
About Question 2: This can be confusing. What you mean is clearly that any two of the circles intersect at some point. What it can be understood after the first question is that all of the circles intersect at the same point on the plane.
On the positive side, that note on tangent circles is great and I like this problem. You have to think a little but the solution is almost trivial to code. If you clarify those little things I mentioned, I will approve it.

One more thing: I don't know why people don't use periods at the end of sentences in the description but it is so much nicer with them.
Fixed all the problems. How does it look?
Each circle intersects each other circle. Updated the statement, thanks

What do you mean by this? Is there something wrong with the answer?

Edit: I've changed the variable name "diffs" to "distances" for readability
I've completely forgot about it, thanks for notifying, added it

Majority of the puzzles don't reveal themselves right away. They at least have a theme or an abstraction layer to make it more interesting. Going with your logic, half of the puzzles wouldn't even exist now, including 2B XOR NOT 2B

Also, once a player recognizes a problem, they'll just reapply their previous solution unless it's the shortest mode. So it's always unfair if a player knows the puzzle beforehand, please don't make it sound like the problem only exists for this puzzle

Which part of the statement is unclear?

Edit: I'm heading to bed, will answer you tomorrow, sorry about that, timezones suck

I think I kind of get it now. I missed the "centre's coordinate". I somehow thought there is a circle growing outward from (0,0) each turn. I get burned by the poor reading comprehension all the time.

So algorithm basically is to calculate the minimum and maximum distance between 2 points, what is the reasoning behind doing %2 at the end after you halved the distance?

Lets say that your min distance is 3. Next turn, it'll be 1 and -1 the turn after. So it takes 2 turns for distance of 3 to be closed. If I only divide it by 2, I'll get 1, so I need to check if it has a remainder
The fact that, problably more than, half of existing problems are too cleary trivial is not IMHO a valid reason to continue.
You've missed the point here. I was defending that having a theme or an abstraction layer isn't just "boring text". Triviality of the puzzle is another thing
max_dist and min_dist between two points.....

Yeah, I've figured it out and changed just before you commented :D
Also, did you really refuse just because of the variable naming? I mean, you could just notify me about it, it's quite minor and a trivial fix
What ??? No of course. I just do not see the interest of a problem consisting in finding max and min distance of a set of points.

Ah, fair enough. But I believe wording is quite important here, I could just ask for the min and max distances right away but instead, I've tried to make it in a way that it forces you to find the real definition of the question

The same applies to my 2B XOR NOT 2B puzzle:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/188195a5500fd29e9c6cd31e4124a90755a5
I could just ask to find the cycles but instead, I've hid cyclical nature of the question within the test cases. It forces people to come to a realization that optimization is needed

The same also applies to Folding paper:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1875dbf6b45e6f82f03420ba708f18d38334

I've made a little fix in the first sentence:
You are given n circles and their centre coordinates
to
You are given n circles and their centres' coordinates
As it is both plural and possessive. Otherwise I like it.
Thanks!
